Award.AwardTitle: Controlling Quantum Devices: Virtual Systems and the Challenge of Scaling
Award.AbstractNarration:
Two important challenges in the control of quantum devices will be addressed in this project. The first involves the cooling and control of nano-mechanical resonators. A method will be developed that exploits quantum error-correction to increase the accuracy of control via superconducting circuits. The second challenge is designing fast and efficient implementations for complex quantum circuits for control and computation. Various approaches aimed at reducing the computing power needed to optimize such circuits will be investigated.

As part of the project, graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in high-performance computing. Student access to parallel computing will be supported and strengthened at Williams College and the University of Massachusetts at Boston (UMB). The project will further develop a research and mentoring collaboration between Williams College, an outstanding undergraduate institution, and UMB, a public urban graduate institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The strange behavior of microscopic systems such as atoms, electrons, and photons, referred to as quantum dynamics, can now be realized in experimental superconducting electronic and electro-mechanical circuits. To use these circuits in future technologies they must be coaxed to behave in specific ways. A powerful method for engineering such specific behavior is to apply controls, usually electic or magnetic fields and power sources, and to vary these applied forces in precisely chosen ways. A specific recipe for varying a set of controls is called a control "protocol". Finding control protocols that will achieve a given behavior is a difficult problem, however, and becomes even more difficult as the complexity of a circuit increases. Not only is it necessary to engineer a specific behavior but it is also important do so in the fastest way possible. It will already be familiar that the speed at which computers run is very important, because the faster they are the more they are able to accomplish in real-time applications, such as processing video streams or performing image recognition.

The primary outcomes of this NSF funded research project were the discovery of a new method for finding maximum-speed control protocols for a class of applications that is much faster than previous methods, and the discovery that another, recently introduced method for finding such protocols is very effective for ceratin especially difficult applications.
